messageBody:
On 12/27/06, junitheadache <bohs01@...> wrote:
> hmm, to be honest, I haven't had much experience with TDD or JUnit
> till I started on my honors project about a couple of months ago.
> I've done much research however and have written a small lab
> excercise using TDD.
>
> As for what makes me think its a good idea, well basically all the
> articles I read and the people I've spoken to remark on two reasons
> why people do not pick up TDD, firstly being the test-first concept
> of it is difficult to grasp and secondly that they do not see the
> benefits in using it.
>

As several other people have stated, TDD is not (primarily) about
testing. It is about design.

There is value, though, in generating JUnit tests both for people who
are not able or not willing to do TDD. We (Agitar) have been working
on this problem and have an experimental version of our test
generation engine available at www.junitfactory.com. There is a free
demo online and I can get an invitation for anyone who would like to
try it for real in Eclipse.

It is primarily designed for people who do not do TDD but we,
internally, find it a useful complement to cover the cases that TDD
misses or to bring legacy code under test in the way that Michael
Feathers describes in Working Effectively with Legacy Code.


Kevin

www.junitfactory.com
You send us code. We send you tests.
